Two fires rage on the Port Hills as one enters the Christchurch Adventure Park Last updated 20:22, February 14 2017 GEORGE HEARD/STUFF.CO.NZ 
Fire crews are getting a blaze in Christchurch's Port Hills under control. 
The new, multimillion-dollar Christchurch Adventure Park (CAP) is under threat from fire, as firefighters struggle with two huge blazes in the Port Hills. 
CAP spokeswoman Anne Newman confirmed the fire was in the park's grounds. 
"It's dangerously close to the top [chairlift] station." ALDEN WILLIAMS/FAIRFAX NZ 
The multi-million dollar Christchurch Adventure Park opened in December last year. 
The park cost $20 million dollars to build and only opened on December 17 last year after an eight-month build process. 
READ MORE: 
Newman said fire retardant had been air-dropped on the top station earlier in the day. TIM MCGINN 
A plane drops fire retardant onto a blaze near the Sign of the Kiwi on Christchurch's Port Hills. 
Selwyn District Council principal rural fire officer Douglas Marshall said: "We still have crews on the ground so they will be dealing with that if there is an issue." 
Firefighters earlier said two huge blazes in Christchurch's Port Hills had now contained, although the battle to put them out was continuing. 
Resources have been stretched between two scrub fires â€“ the first in Lansdowne on Early Valley Rd, and a second that started in a car park near Marleys Hill, off Summit Rd. TIM MCGINN 
A helicopter fills a monsoon bucket from a small pond near Sugarloaf on the Port Hills. 
Parts of the Early Valley Rd fire had crossed Summit Rd towards Governors Bay on Tuesday, but homes in the area are no longer believed to be at risk. 
A helicopter fighting the fires crashed near Sugarloaf about 2.50pm on Tuesday. Police confirmed the pilot, a man had died. 
Up to 15 helicopters had been fighting the blaze, and all had been grounded following the crash. Pilots were given the option to return to the skies in the evening, with some choosing not to take to the skies following the crash. JOHN KIRK-ANDERSON/FAIRFAX NZ 
Fire burning down towards Governors Bay from Summit Rd. Ohinetahi homestead can be seen at the bottom of the image. 
The blazes, which both started on Monday, had spread over 600 hectares. It was expected firefighters would be needed for another two or three days. 
The Selwyn District Council said the Marley Hill fire appeared to be largely contained on the city side of Summit Rd by 3pm. 
Marshall said the fire had damaged about 548 hectares on Early Valley Rd about about 36 hectares on Marley Hill. GEORGE HEARD/FAIRFAX NZ 
The blazes could take days to finally put out. 
"We've had one house lost, another slightly damaged, a number of outbuildings and there's been a significant amount of vegetation." 
Governors Bay resident Tony Edney said on Tuesday he could see the fire burning vigorously along the upper slopes of the Port Hills and along the east side of Mt Ada, above Ella's Track. 
He thought the top of the Ohinetahi Reserve had been affected and said the fire seemed to be heading towards the Sign of the Bellbird. GEORGE HEARD/FAIRFAX NZ 
Melted metal pools beneath a burned out car in the aftermath of huge blazes on Christchurch's Port Hills. 
"It's impossible to see what's happening, and it's very confusing. There's ash falling all around an a think smoke haze, it's giving us headaches." 
"It's a pretty catastrophic event for everyone," he said. 
Both fires had burned through over 600 hectares of scrub, destroying at least one home and several sheds, closing multiple roads, and cutting power to 50 houses. A second house was slightly damaged by fire. All affected structures were in the Landsdowne area. ALDEN WILLIAMS/Stuff.co.nz 
Superintendent Lane Todd speaks to the media on Tuesday. 
It was understood the Landsdowne fire was related to an electrical fault and was not being treated as suspicious. 
A Selwyn District Council spokesman said he did not know the cause of the fire, but a fire investigator would work to determine the cause. 
OVERNIGHT EVACUATIONS GEORGE HEARD/FAIRFAX NZ 
Scorched earth and burnt debris on Christchurch's Port Hills in the wake of huge fires. 
Twenty-four homes had to be evacuated overnight, and a group of children were among those rescued on Monday after becoming stuck near one of the fires. 
Selwyn principal rural fire officer Douglas Marshall said 11 helicopters and nearly 120 firefighters were working to contain the fires on Tuesday, and could be needed for another two or three days. Three two-member firefighting crews from the New Zealand Army had also been dispatched to help. 
"The second fire . . . [at Marleys Hill] is working around the radio mast that's up in that area. It's currently working down a ridge it's probably the top end of the [Christchurch] Adventure Park area," Marshall said. "It's not contained. It's still burning quite strong. 
"We would certainly encourage residents not to be up there at the present time. We understand they want to protect their houses but it's much better if they're not here." 
Power had been lost to 50 homes after the fires caused significant damage to 19 power poles in Early Valley Rd and two in the area of Dyers Pass and Summit roads. GEORGE HEARD/FAIRFAX NZ 
Helicopters with monsoon buckets were used to try and control the blaze. 
Lines company Orion said the poles needed to be replaced, but access was restricted due to the fires. 
It was hoped power could be restored within the next few days. 
The Christchurch Adventure Park was closed on Tuesday, and local radio station RDU was off the air after power was cut from the Marley's Hill transmission site. 1 NEWS 
Fire crews are out in force today as two blazes continue to burn. 
RDU station director James Meharry said they were exploring options to get back on air. 
He said the feed was likely to be out for a couple of days and he understood several major companies had transmission boxes on the site, including Spark. 
MCCAW HELPING FIRE EFFORT 
A line of flames burns across the Port Hills. 
Former All Black captain Richie McCaw is among those helping people affected by the fires. 
Christchurch Helicopters pilot Kevin Walsh said McCaw had been moving people out of affected areas by helicopter since Monday afternoon. 
"He's not doing any of the bucketing work, one of our other pilots are doing that, so he's just picking people up and getting them out." JOHN KIRK-ANDERSON/FAIRFAX NZ 
A fire on the Port Hills, viewed from Osterholts Rd, Tai Tapu, on Tuesday morning. 
"It's another day at the office for him", Walsh said. 
Ben Robinson, a pilot at Ravensdown, was in a fixed-wing plane spreading flame retardant to contain the fire's spread on Tuesday. 
The retardant was dropped in a line where it would serve as a barrier, redirecting the fire to where it could be more easily managed, he said. GEORGE HEARD/STUFF.CO.NZ 
Out of control fires in Christchurch. 
"There's plenty of wind fanning it but it's not really getting too close to anything. 
"They're doing everything they can to squeeze it up and bring one side of the fire in and hopefully track it a different way." 
Fire Service area commander Dave Berry said they received reports a group of children were on the Port Hills near the fire on Monday afternoon. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
Two fires on the Port Hills continued burning uncontained overnight. 
"We flew a helicopter in and picked up some children." 
Several people at houses in the affected area were also flown out. 
People would be feeling unsettled by the blazes, but needed to stay well clear, he said. 
"Our advice to the public is to please stay away from the scene." 
TWENTY-FOUR HOMES EVACUATED 
A Fire Service spokesman said the Summit Rd fire had spread across 1.5 kilometres. 
The flames were too aggressive to battle in the dark, so firefighters working overnight concentrated on trying to stop it spreading further. 
A Civil Defence spokesman said about 20 houses on Early Valley Rd and four on Summit Rd were evacuated overnight. Tai Tapu School had been available for those needing somewhere to go, but had closed before midnight. 
Road closures are still in place for Early Valley Rd, Old Tai Tapu Rd between Osterholts Rd and State Highway 75, and Summit Rd between Dyers Pass and Rapaki Track on Tuesday. 
Dyers Pass Rd is also closed between Hackthorne and Governors Bay roads, and will remain closed on Wednesday. Drivers are advised to use the Lyttelton Tunnel or Gebbies Pass instead. Holmes Rd and Holmeswood Rise reopened about 12.30pm and residents were allowed back in their homes. 
WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW 
- Up to 15 helicopters, 10 rural tankers and one New Zealand Defence Force tanker are being used to battle the two fires on Christchurch's Port Hills. 
- 120 firefighters and three two-person New Zealand Army teams are working to contain the blazes. 
- One house and several sheds have been destroyed. There are unconfirmed reports another two houses have been burned. 
- Twenty houses on Early Valley Rd and four on Summit Rd were evacuated overnight. 
- Road closures are still in place for Early Valley Rd, Old Tai Tapu Rd between Osterholts Rd and State Highway 75, Summit Rd between Dyers Pass and Rapaki Track, and Dyers Pass Rd between Hackthorne and Governors Bay roads. Dyers Pass Rd will remain closed on Wednesday. 
- A no fly zone is in place for the area bound by Princess Margaret Hospital, Sugarloaf, Teddington, and Tai Tapu until midday Friday. 
- The Christchurch Adventure Park is closed on Tuesday. 
- The fires may cause health issues for some Cantabrians, with smoke possibly irritating eyes, noses, throats and airways. The Canterbury District Health Board says most symptoms will disappear soon after exposure to smoke ends. Medical treatment should be sought if symptoms worsen, especially for those with asthma, or lung or heart disease. Call 111 in an emergency, but call your usual general practice team for all other health care needs.
